questions.question: 1. What is a granuloma?
options: A collection of neutrophils in acute inflammation
A focus of chronic specific inflammation consisting of activated macrophages transformed into epithelioid cells, surrounded by lymphocytes
A type of fibrotic scar without inflammation
A cluster of fibroblasts and collagen only

questions.question: 2. What is the typical size of a granuloma?
3. Which cells primarily form the core of a granuloma?
options: Epithelioid cells derived from activated macrophages

questions.question: 4. What are the two main types of granulomas based on their pathogenesis?
options: Foreign body granulomas and immune granulomas

questions.question: 5. Foreign body granulomas are incited by which of the following?
options: Inert foreign bodies such as talc, sutures, or fibers

questions.question: 6. Why do foreign body granulomas form?
options: Because the foreign bodies are too small to be detected
Because the foreign bodies are too large to be phagocytosed by a single macrophage
Due to an immediate allergic response
Because they induce a massive neutrophilic reaction

questions.question: 7. Immune granulomas are typically incited by which agents?
options: Agents that are poorly degradable or particulate such as Mycobacterium tuberculosis

16. What is the role of macrophage migration inhibitory factor in granuloma formation?
options: It helps to localize activated macrophages and epithelioid cells

questions.question: 17. What morphological transformation do activated macrophages undergo in granuloma formation?
options: They become multinucleated giant cells directly

questions.question: 18. How are giant cells formed in granulomas?
19. How are Langhans-type giant cells characterized?
options: Nuclei arranged in a peripheral, horseshoe pattern

questions.question: 20. Is there a functional difference between Langhans-type and foreign body–type giant cells?
options: Yes, Langhans-type are more effective in phagocytosis
Yes, foreign body–type produce more cytokines
No, there is no functional difference
Yes, they differ in antigen presentation

questions.question: 21. In H&E staining, epithelioid cells typically show:
options: Pale pink granular cytoplasm with indistinct cell borders

questions.question: 35. Which cells typically form the lymphocyte collar around a granuloma?
options: Lymphocytes (mostly T cells) and occasionally plasma cells

questions.question: 36. What effect does TGF-β produced by activated macrophages have in granuloma formation?
options: It promotes fibroblast proliferation and fibrosis

questions.question: 37. In foreign body granulomas, what is typically found at the center of the lesion?
options: The inert foreign material (e.g., talc or suture)

questions.question: 38. Immune granulomas are primarily associated with which type of immune response?
39. Which statement best characterizes granulomatous inflammation?
options: It is a nonspecific, acute inflammatory response with abundant neutrophils
It is a specific pattern of chronic inflammation characterized by organized aggregates of epithelioid cells, giant cells, lymphocytes, and fibrosis
It involves only fibroblast proliferation with no cellular infiltrate
It is primarily mediated by IgE antibodies

questions.question: 40. Which of the following best summarizes the formation of a granuloma in immune-mediated chronic inflammation?
options: Macrophages ingest antigens, present them on MHC II, induce TH1 differentiation, secrete IFN-γ and IL-2, activate more macrophages, and form epithelioid cells that fuse into giant cells with a surrounding lymphocyte collar
Neutrophils accumulate and release enzymes to form a pus-filled cavity
B cells produce antibodies that directly cause tissue necrosis
Fibroblasts immediately replace injured tissue without immune involvement
